elements.clean_text:
Abstract
In this work, the rod-like ligand 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)-benzene (bib) has been utilized as a building block to perform counterion researches on the structural diversities of coordination polymers. A series of new manganese compounds, {[Mn(bib)3(ClO4)2](CHCl3)2}
n
 (1), [Mn(bib)2(N3)2]
n
 (2), [Mn(bib)2(HCO2)2]
n
 (3), [Mn(bib)2(Ac)2]
n
 (4), {[Mn(bib)2(CF3SO3)2](CH2Cl2)4}
n
 (5), and [Mn(bib)2(SO4)]
n
 (6) have been successfully synthesized. Compound 1 shows a 3D interpenetrating α-Po network only based on the bib linker. Compounds 2 and 3 exhibit a 2D (4,4) layer with parallel and incline interpenetration, respectively. Compounds 4 and 5 display a parallel-packing 2D (4,4) layer with the porosity of 23.4% and 61.4%, respectively. Compound 6 furnishes a 3D α-Po framework with a 2D (4,4) layer pillared by the μ2-SO4
2− ion. The structural diversities among 1–6 have been carefully discussed, and the roles of counterions (from coordination affinity and molecular size) in the self-assembly of coordination polymers have also been well documented. Furthermore, magnetic properties of 6 have been carefully studied.

Compounds 4 and 5 exhibit 3D packing porous architectures.
The tunable effect of counterion has been documented.

Introduction
Coordination polymers have attracted a great deal of recent attention, which is propelled by the aesthetic structure and topological feature as well as the potential applications in the gas storage, molecular magnet and so on . The rapid growth in this area continues to provide a large number of functional materials with various fascinating topologies, and also has witnessed many comprehensive discussions on the control over the topological framework . However, it is still a great challenge to rationally construct coordination polymers with predicted structures, especially characteristic elements closely related to the functionality, such as the porosity, entanglement and magnetic coupling mediator. The ligand backbone seems to be most important for the final structure , but factors affecting the topological framework are intricate and diverse in the formation of coordination polymers, including the coordination nature of metal node , solvent  and so on.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">As an indispensable part of coordination polymers, the counterion has a great effect on the structure owing to the discrepancy of coordination affinity and molecular size . The counterion with strong coordination ability could be viewed as a specific ligand, and thus it is significant for the extension of metal node, directly related to the topology and dimensionality. Furthermore, the coordinated counterion obviously exerts an influence on the volume of coordination sphere of metal node, which is closely relevant to the entanglement and porosity. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate the correlation between the counterion and topological structure, which is beneficial to interpret the law of self-assemble in coordination polymers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As an indispensable part of coordination polymers, the counterion has a great effect on the structure owing to the discrepancy of coordination affinity and molecular size . The counterion with strong coordination ability could be viewed as a specific ligand, and thus it is significant for the extension of metal node, directly related to the topology and dimensionality. Furthermore, the coordinated counterion obviously exerts an influence on the volume of coordination sphere of metal node, which is closely relevant to the entanglement and porosity. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate the correlation between the counterion and topological structure, which is beneficial to interpret the law of self-assemble in coordination polymers.

In this paper, compound 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (<ce:bold>bib</ce:bold>) is chosen as the ligand to react with a series of manganese salts by employing different counterions. Because of the strong coordinating ability of imidazole, the research of imidazole-containing ligands has experienced a drastic development . The coordination chemistry of rigid bis(imidazole) ligands have been continuously explored in our group, and they are good candidates for the construction of porous or interpenetrating architecture due to the rod-like long backbone . In this paper, compound 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)benzene (bib) is chosen as the ligand to react with a series of manganese salts by employing different counterions. Via the above parallel processing method, six coordination polymers, {[Mn(bib)3(ClO4)2](CHCl3)2}
n
 (1), [Mn(bib)2(N3)2]
n
 (2), [Mn(bib)2(HCO2)2]
n
 (3), [Mn(bib)2(Ac)2]
n
 (4), {[Mn(bib)2(CF3SO3)2](CH2Cl2)4}
n
 (5) and [Mn(bib)2(SO4)]
n
 (6) have been obtained. All compounds have been characterized by elemental analysis and IR, and their crystal structures are elucidated by X-ray crystallography. The structural correlation has been carefully discussed to give a systematic research on the effect of counterion. In addition, compound 6 shows a 1D [-SO4-Mn-]
∞
 magnetic unit, and magnetic properties have been well studied by fitting the experimental data.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0030">Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0035">Materials and general methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">All the starting materials and reagents were commercially obtained and used without any further purification. The ligand <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> was synthesized according to the reported procedure . Elemental analyses of C, H and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>C analyzer. IR spectra were measured on a TENSOR 27 (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kV, 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromater. Magnetic data were collected on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer equipped with a 5T magnet using crushed crystals of the sample. The diamagnetic corrections were calculated using Pascal’s constants.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental section
Materials and general methods
All the starting materials and reagents were commercially obtained and used without any further purification. The ligand bib was synthesized according to the reported procedure . Elemental analyses of C, H and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. IR spectra were measured on a TENSOR 27 (Bruker) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was recorded on a Rigaku D/Max-2500 diffractometer at 40kV, 100mA for a Cu-target tube and a graphite monochromater. Magnetic data were collected on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer equipped with a 5T magnet using crushed crystals of the sample. The diamagnetic corrections were calculated using Pascal’s constants.

The resultant solution was left to stand at room temperature for about three weeks. Then colorless block crystals suitable for X-ray crystal analysis were obtained by filtration. elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of complexes
{[Mn(bib)3(ClO4)2](CHCl3)2}
∞
(1)
A mixture of CH3OH and CHCl3 (8mL, 1:1 v/v), as a buffer layer, was carefully layered over a solution of bib (31.5mg, 0.15mmol) in CHCl3 (6mL). A solution of Mn(ClO4)2·6H2O (18mg, 0.05mmol) in CH3OH (6mL) was then layered over the buffer layer. The resultant solution was left to stand at room temperature for about three weeks. Then colorless block crystals suitable for X-ray crystal analysis were obtained by filtration. Yield: ~65% based on bib. elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0075">X-ray data collection and structure determinations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Suitable X-ray single crystals diffraction data of <ce:bold>1–6</ce:bold> were selected and mounted on a Rigaku MM-007/Saturn 70 with graphite monochromatic Mo-<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>α radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles . All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL . Metal atoms in each complex was located from the <ce:italic>E</ce:italic>-maps and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. The hydrogen atoms were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically. Further details for structural analysis are summarized in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>
, and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray data collection and structure determinations
Suitable X-ray single crystals diffraction data of 1–6 were selected and mounted on a Rigaku MM-007/Saturn 70 with graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles . All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL . Metal atoms in each complex was located from the E-maps and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on F
2. The hydrogen atoms were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically. Further details for structural analysis are summarized in 
, and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0080">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0085">Description of crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0090">{[Mn(bib)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>∞</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>, and the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion locates at the inversion center. As show in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>
a, the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion lies in a distorted octahedral coordination environment, which is surrounded by six imidazole rings of distinct <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligands. The lengths of equatorial bonds are 2.258(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, with an elongation to 2.307(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for axial bonds, which are all in good agreement with those typically observed () .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Description of crystal structures
{[Mn(bib)3(ClO4)2](CHCl3)2}
∞
 (1)
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n, and the MnII ion locates at the inversion center. As show in 
a, the MnII ion lies in a distorted octahedral coordination environment, which is surrounded by six imidazole rings of distinct bib ligands. The lengths of equatorial bonds are 2.258(5)Å, with an elongation to 2.307(5)Å for axial bonds, which are all in good agreement with those typically observed () .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0090" view="all">Notably, the structural moiety is the “hexa-star”, in which the metal center acts as a six-connected node and <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand acts as a linear spoke. The “hexa-star” expands into infinite helices to afford a 1D trigonal aperture along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (b). The screw distance, given by the distance between equivalent atoms generated by one full rotation of 3-fold screw axis, is about 16.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Further analysis reveals that the 1D aperture is reinforced with another infinite helix from the second framework. That is, each aperture is surrounded by two synchronous helices from individual frameworks. However, these 1D trigonal apertures are packed in an antiparallel manner with different chirality, leading to a centrosymmetric and achiral coordination polymer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Notably, the structural moiety is the “hexa-star”, in which the metal center acts as a six-connected node and bib ligand acts as a linear spoke. The “hexa-star” expands into infinite helices to afford a 1D trigonal aperture along the a axis (b). The screw distance, given by the distance between equivalent atoms generated by one full rotation of 3-fold screw axis, is about 16.6Å. Further analysis reveals that the 1D aperture is reinforced with another infinite helix from the second framework. That is, each aperture is surrounded by two synchronous helices from individual frameworks. However, these 1D trigonal apertures are packed in an antiparallel manner with different chirality, leading to a centrosymmetric and achiral coordination polymer.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">As exhibited by the infinite double-stranded helix, the most fascinating structural feature of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is that the architecture is composed of two equivalent frameworks. Topological analysis suggests that these two independent frameworks are interlocked with each other to give an interpenetrating α-Po network (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>
a) . As a consequence, the overall void volume after interpenetration is about 907.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, i.e. 38.3% of the cell volume using the PLATON program . Unfortunately, the void space in the aperture is occupied by the ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counterion and chloroform molecule (b).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
As exhibited by the infinite double-stranded helix, the most fascinating structural feature of 1 is that the architecture is composed of two equivalent frameworks. Topological analysis suggests that these two independent frameworks are interlocked with each other to give an interpenetrating α-Po network (
a) . As a consequence, the overall void volume after interpenetration is about 907.4Å3, i.e. 38.3% of the cell volume using the PLATON program . Unfortunately, the void space in the aperture is occupied by the ClO4
− counterion and chloroform molecule (b).

Different from the homoleptic coordination geometry of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, herein the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion lies in a heteroleptic (4+2) environment. As show in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>

Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with one MnII ion located at the inversion center. Different from the homoleptic coordination geometry of 1, herein the MnII ion lies in a heteroleptic (4+2) environment. As show in 
a, the MnII ion is coordinated by six N atoms from four bib ligands and two azide ions, which hold the equatorial and axial positions, respectively. The Mn–N coordination bond lengths are in the range of 2.230(2)–2.278(2)Å, comparable to the corresponding above value.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0105" view="all">The <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand takes a bidentate mode to connect two Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions, and each Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion is surrounded by four <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligands, which further extends into a 2D (4,4) lattice if the ligand <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> simplified as a linear linker (b). Due to the long edge provided by the rod-like building block <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold>, the 2D layer shows a nano-grid of approximately 13.4×13.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> in dimensions. However, the grid center of one corrugated layer is occupied by the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion from the other layer. That is to say, the large window of one layer is pierced by the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand from another layer. Further topological analysis suggests that two identical (4,4) sheets are interlocked with each other to form a parallel interpenetration (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>
a) . Moreover, these double-layer architectures are packed tightly in an ABAB mode along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis to afford 3D supermolecular framework (b). The N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counterion is dispersed in the supermolecular framework to balance the positive charge.</ce:para>

Due to the long edge provided by the rod-like building block bib, the 2D layer shows a nano-grid of approximately 13.4×13.4Å2 in dimensions. − counterion is dispersed in the supermolecular framework to balance the positive charge.

Compound 5 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1 with one MnII ion located at the inversion center. The asymmetric unit contains one half of MnII ion, one bib ligands, one CF3SO3
− ion and two dichloromethane molecules. The MnII ion still lies in a heteroleptic (4+2) coordination environment, but the axial sites are occupied by two CF3SO3
− oxygen atoms (
a). The Mn–N bond lengths are 2.234(3)Å and 2.242(3)Å, Mn–O bond length are 2.229(3)Å, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0135" view="all">The <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand takes a bidentate mode to bridges the 4-connected Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion to finally form a 2D (4,4) layer if the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand is simplified as a linear linker (b). These 2D (4,4) layers are piled up together in a parallel pattern to exhibit a 1D parallelogram channel with the dimensions of approximately 10.2×12.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (). The 3D packing architecture shows large void space of about 711.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, i.e. 61.4% of the cell volume using the PLATON program. However, the available void space is greatly reduced by the CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counterion, which locates in the 1D channel (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>
a). Interestingly, the overall void volume of the neutral supermolecular framework is still up to about 478.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, i.e. 41.3% of the cell volume, which is filled with the dichloromethane molecule (b). Unfortunately, when the as-synthesized crystals were taken out from the solution, and placed in the air at room temperature for about 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, the original shape was destroyed and large crystals gradually collapsed into a mass of powder. The XRPD reveals that the collapsed powder was not matched with the crystal sample (). Furthermore, the collapsed powder exhibits no gas adsorption for N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Thus crystals of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> may convert into another tight coordination polymer in the air, which is failed to be characterized by the X-ray crystallography although trying our best.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The bib ligand takes a bidentate mode to bridges the 4-connected MnII ion to finally form a 2D (4,4) layer if the bib ligand is simplified as a linear linker (b). These 2D (4,4) layers are piled up together in a parallel pattern to exhibit a 1D parallelogram channel with the dimensions of approximately 10.2×12.4Å2 along the a axis (). The 3D packing architecture shows large void space of about 711.5Å3, i.e. 61.4% of the cell volume using the PLATON program. However, the available void space is greatly reduced by the CF3SO3
− counterion, which locates in the 1D channel (
a). Interestingly, the overall void volume of the neutral supermolecular framework is still up to about 478.4Å3, i.e. 41.3% of the cell volume, which is filled with the dichloromethane molecule (b). Unfortunately, when the as-synthesized crystals were taken out from the solution, and placed in the air at room temperature for about 1h, the original shape was destroyed and large crystals gradually collapsed into a mass of powder. The XRPD reveals that the collapsed powder was not matched with the crystal sample (). Furthermore, the collapsed powder exhibits no gas adsorption for N2. Thus crystals of 5 may convert into another tight coordination polymer in the air, which is failed to be characterized by the X-ray crystallography although trying our best.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0120">The effect of counterion on the topological structure</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0150" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, constructed from the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand and six kinds of manganese salts, illustrate a series of fascinating frameworks based on Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> nodes. In the progress of self-assembly, both the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion and <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand keep its own coordination pattern, the octahedron and bidentate linker, respectively. Significantly, in all of six compounds, four equatorial sites of Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion are exclusively occupied by the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand, and each <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand bridges two Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions. In such a way, the octahedral coordinated Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> is primarily connected by the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand into a 2D (4,4) layer, which can be viewed as a common feature to build up six compounds by different linkers, such as the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand and inorganic anions, and also will keep the consistency and continuity of structural variation. All above similarities greatly facilitates us to perform a systematic study on the effect of counterion on the topological structure. Six kinds of counterions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> play various roles due to different coordination affinities and molecular sizes, and finally lead to diverse frameworks under the cooperation of <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0065"></ce:float-anchor>
).</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0155" view="all">In compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, first, four equatorial sites are coordinated by the bidentate <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand, which links the metal center to form a 2D (4,4) layer. The coordination ability of ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion is very weak, and there is no interaction between the perchloric O atom and Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion. Thus the octahedral Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion is merely coordinated by six <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> imidazole rings, and the above (4,4) layer is further bridged by the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand to afford a pcu framework. Further analysis suggests that these two independent identical frameworks are interlocked with each other to give an interpenetrating α-Po network. The ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counterion is freely dispersed in the void space of entangled architecture.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
In compound 1, first, four equatorial sites are coordinated by the bidentate bib ligand, which links the metal center to form a 2D (4,4) layer. The coordination ability of ClO4
− ion is very weak, and there is no interaction between the perchloric O atom and MnII ion. Thus the octahedral MnII ion is merely coordinated by six bib imidazole rings, and the above (4,4) layer is further bridged by the bib ligand to afford a pcu framework. Further analysis suggests that these two independent identical frameworks are interlocked with each other to give an interpenetrating α-Po network. The ClO4
− counterion is freely dispersed in the void space of entangled architecture.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0160" view="all">For compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, there is a great character in common that the counterion (N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, HCO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, Ac<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> or CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) takes a monodentate mode to bind with the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion on the axial site. Other four equatorial sites are coordinated by the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand, and the bidentate ligand connects the metal center into a 2D (4,4) layer. Nevertheless, compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> exhibit quite a number of differences among the topological structure. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the large window of one (4,4) layer is pierced by the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand from another (4,4) layer, and such two identical 2D sheets are interlocked with each other to form parallel interpenetration. For <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, quadrangular grids of one 2D layer are pierced by the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand from different symmetry-equivalent 2D layers. That is to say, each 2D layer of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is interlocked with infinite parallel layers to form incline interpenetration. However, with regard to <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, the 2D (4,4) layer has no entanglement, and is arranged in a parallel pattern to present 1D parallelogram channels with the dimensions of approximately 6.0×6.0 and 10.2×12.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, respectively. The counterions of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, Ac<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, are larger than three-atom ions in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and HCO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>). Thus compounds <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> have a bulkier metal coordination sphere bound with two counterions, which hinders the happening of entanglement . Furthermore, the volume of CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion is bigger than that of Ac<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion, which makes that compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> has an even larger 1D channel supported by the counterion. The 3D packing architecture of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> shows void space of about 711.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, i.e. 61.4% of the cell volume, also larger than corresponding values of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (315.6 and 23.4%).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
For compounds 2–5, there is a great character in common that the counterion (N3
−, HCO2
−, Ac− or CF3SO3
−) takes a monodentate mode to bind with the MnII ion on the axial site. Other four equatorial sites are coordinated by the bib ligand, and the bidentate ligand connects the metal center into a 2D (4,4) layer. Nevertheless, compounds 2–5 exhibit quite a number of differences among the topological structure. In 2, the large window of one (4,4) layer is pierced by the bib ligand from another (4,4) layer, and such two identical 2D sheets are interlocked with each other to form parallel interpenetration. For 3, quadrangular grids of one 2D layer are pierced by the bib ligand from different symmetry-equivalent 2D layers. That is to say, each 2D layer of 3 is interlocked with infinite parallel layers to form incline interpenetration. However, with regard to 4 and 5, the 2D (4,4) layer has no entanglement, and is arranged in a parallel pattern to present 1D parallelogram channels with the dimensions of approximately 6.0×6.0 and 10.2×12.4Å2, respectively. The counterions of 4 and 5, Ac− and CF3SO3
−, are larger than three-atom ions in 2 and 3 (N3
− and HCO2
−). Thus compounds 4 and 5 have a bulkier metal coordination sphere bound with two counterions, which hinders the happening of entanglement . Furthermore, the volume of CF3SO3
− ion is bigger than that of Ac− ion, which makes that compound 5 has an even larger 1D channel supported by the counterion. The 3D packing architecture of 5 shows void space of about 711.5Å3, i.e. 61.4% of the cell volume, also larger than corresponding values of 4 (315.6 and 23.4%).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0165" view="all">With regard to compound <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, four equatorial sites of the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion are coordinated by the imidazole ring, and the metal center is still linked by the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand to form a 2D (4,4) layer. However, the SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ion, acting as a bidentate ligand, occupies the axial site of Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion, and further bridges the 2D layer to form a 3D pillar-layered framework with the α-Po topology.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
With regard to compound 6, four equatorial sites of the MnII ion are coordinated by the imidazole ring, and the metal center is still linked by the bib ligand to form a 2D (4,4) layer. However, the SO4
2− ion, acting as a bidentate ligand, occupies the axial site of MnII ion, and further bridges the 2D layer to form a 3D pillar-layered framework with the α-Po topology.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0170" view="all">The results indicate that the counterion exert an important influence on the resulting frameworks, and present a feasible strategy for controlling the synthesis of coordination polymer. In compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion is free of coordination, and Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion is homoleptic coordinated by the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand to afford an interpenetrating α-Po network. For compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, the counterion (N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, HCO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, Ac<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> or CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) takes a monodentate mode to bind with the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion on the axial site, and other four equatorial sites of the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion are coordinated by the bidentate <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand to present a 2D (4,4) layer. With regard to compound <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion is still linked by the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand to form a 2D (4,4) layer, and the SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ion further connects the 2D layer into a 3D α-Po framework. Thus the coordination affinity of counterion directly controls the final topological framework, especially the dimensionality. Furthermore, compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (including N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> or HCO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion) exhibit a 2D parallel and incline interpenetrating (4,4) layer, respectively, while compounds <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> (including Ac<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> or CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion) have no interpenetration, which could infer that the small counterion is liable to the entanglement. Finally, the subtle difference in the porosity of frameworks <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> shows that the large counterion is beneficial to the porous coordination polymer. As is well known, the entanglement and porosity are two competitive aspects of satisfaction with the consequence of nature’s <ce:italic>horror vacui</ce:italic>
, which is ideally interpreted by the above positive effect of small and large counterions on the entanglement and porosity, respectively.</ce:para>

The results indicate that the counterion exert an important influence on the resulting frameworks, and present a feasible strategy for controlling the synthesis of coordination polymer. In compounds 1, the ClO4
− ion is free of coordination, and MnII ion is homoleptic coordinated by the bib ligand to afford an interpenetrating α-Po network. For compounds 2–5, the counterion (N3
−, HCO2
−, Ac− or CF3SO3
−) takes a monodentate mode to bind with the MnII ion on the axial site, and other four equatorial sites of the MnII ion are coordinated by the bidentate bib ligand to present a 2D (4,4) layer. With regard to compound 6, the MnII ion is still linked by the bib ligand to form a 2D (4,4) layer, and the SO4
2− ion further connects the 2D layer into a 3D α-Po framework. Thus the coordination affinity of counterion directly controls the final topological framework, especially the dimensionality. Furthermore, compounds 2 and 3 (including N3
− or HCO2
− anion) exhibit a 2D parallel and incline interpenetrating (4,4) layer, respectively, while compounds 4 and 5 (including Ac− or CF3SO3
− anion) have no interpenetration, which could infer that the small counterion is liable to the entanglement. Finally, the subtle difference in the porosity of frameworks 4 and 5 shows that the large counterion is beneficial to the porous coordination polymer. As is well known, the entanglement and porosity are two competitive aspects of satisfaction with the consequence of nature’s horror vacui
, which is ideally interpreted by the above positive effect of small and large counterions on the entanglement and porosity, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0175" view="all">As stated above, there is a common feature of 2D layers [Mn(<ce:bold>bib</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>∞</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, which are all viewed as a (4,4) lattice. Actually, the 2D (4,4) layers exhibit slight differences on the shape due to the varied coordination conformations of <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand. In compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand adopts a trans-conformation to connect the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion into a square lattice with a little deformation (. Taking compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> for example), and the acute angles of these parallelograms are about 73.3, 79.2, 85.7, 73.8 and 83.3°, respectively. However, the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand of compound <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> adopts a cis-conformation to connect the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion into a distorted square (), and the corresponding acute angle is even about 43.7°. Thereby, the conformation of <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand steers the shape of (4,4) lattice. Unfortunately, the conformation of <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand is hardly controlled, because the <ce:italic>σ</ce:italic> bond between the phenyl and imidazole rings can be freely rotated.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
As stated above, there is a common feature of 2D layers [Mn(bib)2]
∞
 for compounds 1–6, which are all viewed as a (4,4) lattice. Actually, the 2D (4,4) layers exhibit slight differences on the shape due to the varied coordination conformations of bib ligand. In compounds 1–5, the bib ligand adopts a trans-conformation to connect the MnII ion into a square lattice with a little deformation (. Taking compound 2 for example), and the acute angles of these parallelograms are about 73.3, 79.2, 85.7, 73.8 and 83.3°, respectively. However, the bib ligand of compound 6 adopts a cis-conformation to connect the MnII ion into a distorted square (), and the corresponding acute angle is even about 43.7°. Thereby, the conformation of bib ligand steers the shape of (4,4) lattice. Unfortunately, the conformation of bib ligand is hardly controlled, because the σ bond between the phenyl and imidazole rings can be freely rotated.

Magnetic properties of compound 6

Magnetic data were collected by using crushed crystals of 6, which is confirmed the phase purity by a comparison between the experimental and simulated XRPD patterns (). The magnetic susceptibility (χ
M) was measured under 1kOe in the range of 2–300K (
). The χ
M
T value per MnII ion at 300K is about 4.57cm3
Kmol−1, in agreement with the spin-only value for an isolated MnII ion with S=5/2 and g=2.0 (4.38cm3
Kmol−1). As the temperature lowered, the χ
M
T product decreases slowly in the high-temperature range, and decrease more rapidly blow 50K. The decrease of χ
M
T clearly indicates the antiferromagnetic (AFM) coupling interaction between metal centers. The data follow the Curie–Weiss law with C=4.69cm3
Kmol−1 and θ=−2.63K. The negative θ value also indicates the AFM coupling between metal ions, and C value is as expected for the MnII system .

<ce:section-title id="sect0130">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0195" view="all">In this work, a series of coordination polymers based on equatorial 2D (4,4) layers have been successfully synthesized from reactions of the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand with six kinds of manganese salts. Owing to the diversities on the coordination affinity of counterions, the equatorial 2D layers are further bridged by different linkers to form a 3D homoleptic α-Po framework (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), unchanged 2D (4,4) layer (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) and 3D heteroleptic α-Po framework, respectively. Thus the coordination affinity of counterion directly controls the final topological framework, especially the dimensionality. Furthermore, parallel and incline interpenetration is exhibited in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively, which shows that the small counterion is liable to the entanglement. Finally, different porosity of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> reveals that the large counterion is beneficial to porous coordination polymers. Moreover, magnetic studies display that weak ferromagnetic coupling is conducted by the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ion within the 1D SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>–Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> chain of <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
In this work, a series of coordination polymers based on equatorial 2D (4,4) layers have been successfully synthesized from reactions of the bib ligand with six kinds of manganese salts. Owing to the diversities on the coordination affinity of counterions, the equatorial 2D layers are further bridged by different linkers to form a 3D homoleptic α-Po framework (1), unchanged 2D (4,4) layer (2–5) and 3D heteroleptic α-Po framework, respectively. Thus the coordination affinity of counterion directly controls the final topological framework, especially the dimensionality. Furthermore, parallel and incline interpenetration is exhibited in 2 and 3, respectively, which shows that the small counterion is liable to the entanglement. Finally, different porosity of 4 and 5 reveals that the large counterion is beneficial to porous coordination polymers. Moreover, magnetic studies display that weak ferromagnetic coupling is conducted by the μ2-SO4
2− ion within the 1D SO4
2−–Mn2+ chain of 6.
